customer_reviews.title: Convenient but fragile
customer_reviews.text: Broke one by pinching the rim too hard. I have many stemmed and stemless Reidel wine glasses. Used these for the first time and broke one when I was washing them by hand. I tried to lift the wine glass by pinching the rim and it cracked. First Reidel glass I have cracked, so I will assume I was too rough. I like the convenience of stemless wine glasses. I bought them to use when I eat outside. Don’t want the wind to knock over my stemmed glasses.
customer_reviews.author: P Yew

customer_reviews.title: Nice glasses but don't be tempted by Riedel's offer of a different set of wine glasses for each type of wine.
customer_reviews.text: A good addition to my modest collection of wine glasses. But it's a bit much that Riedel has decided to offer slightly different sizes and shapes of glasses for each major type of wine. This is the ultimate in what economists and call "product differentiation," a well-worn marketing strategy to expand the market for the original product. Offering wine-specific glasses is based on the dubious assumption that a wine will taste better in a glass that is designed especially for it. Red wines might arguably need bigger glasses for wine fresh out of the bottle that needs to breathe a bit -- for sippers who can't wait for that first sip. But a little patience eliminates even that justification.
